user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemGive_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemGive_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     * Note there is a possibility that another thread is concurrently taking this sem,
     * and has just checked the current_value but not yet inside the cond_wait call.
     *
     * To address this possibility - the lock must be taken here.  This is unfortunate
     * as it means there may be a task switch when _giving_ a binary semaphore.  But the
     * alternative of having a BinSemGive not wake up the other thread is a bigger issue.
     *
     * Counting sems do not suffer from this, as there is a native POSIX mechanism for those.
     *
     * Note: This lock should be readily available, with only minimal delay if any.
     * If a long delay occurs here, it means something is fundamentally wrong.
     */

    /* Lock the mutex ( not the table! ) */
    if (OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(&sem->id) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /* Binary semaphores are always set as "1" when given */
    sem->current_value = 1;

    /* unblock one thread that is waiting on this sem */
    pthread_cond_signal(&(sem->cv));

    pthread_mutex_unlock(&(sem->id));

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemGive_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_bin_sem_table[OS_MAX_BIN_SEMAPHORES]
...
int32 OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(pthread_mutex_t *mut)
{
    struct timespec timeout;

    if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    timeout.tv_sec += OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS;

    if (pthread_mutex_timedlock(mut, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 prohibits using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. I inspected all provided code fragments (OS_BinSemGive_Impl, OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, and the declaration of OS_impl_bin_sem_table). None of these fragments contain any use of memcmp, strcmp, strncmp, or any other string-comparison function. The semaphore code manipulates integer fields (sem->current_value), pthread primitives (pthread_cond_signal, pthread_mutex_unlock, pthread_mutex_timedlock), and clock_gettime — none of which involve comparing null-terminated strings with memcmp.

Note: The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET is referenced but its definition was not provided; since its implementation is not in the supplied code, it cannot be analyzed here. If that macro (or any omitted code) uses memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, it would be a violation, but there is no evidence of such use in the presented code fragments. Therefore there are no suspicious fragments to report from the given code.
